Could be recency bias, but I know a good number of folks underemployed who are willing to work hard in the industrial age/paint by numbers ethos. (Missing the creativity and risk tolerance to strike out on their own)

A little patronizing and condescending, but think of those who have less than you. 

It makes it easier to see the abundance you do have.

My biggest fear is losing the closeness and positivity once it opens to more people and opposing views. Some folks only know how to debate in zerosum, toxic ways.

We are already seeing bitcoin/crypto adoption in countries with high inflation or histories of high inflation. So, that’s who will go first. 

Last will be the current powers, US, EU, western cultures. Ones too wrapped up in woke narratives and who still think crypto is bad for the environment.

My guess would prioritize towards:
1) bitcoin/ethereum
2) native token
3) stablecoins

The existing infrastructure in the big two allows remittances to be sent today. So that is deep lockin. 

A native token or CBDC might make sense for some nations, but its close to replicating the current problems of fiat currencies or worse. 

I’m pessimistic on stablecoins after events of Terra, FTT, and Tether.

Agree. I don’t have a theory on how to get past the value fluctuations yet. 

I don’t think there’s enough difference between algorithmic vs fiat stablecoins. They still have the same weakness to bank runs as we’re seeing.
Great if you get the opportunity, but what are the alternatives for those less lucky?
It feels like we’re close to a point where user sentiment (tone of posts or reviews) can be mass analyzed by AI.

I like this simple one I’ve been using the past few years. Forgot where it’s from. 

1) Most important thing that happened to you this year? 
2) Why is that important?
3) What else happened?
4) What else did you learn or was a gain?

This. 

Also it’s why this four team format was flawed to begin with. 

Expansion makes the most sense.
